social_history.other: Eats meals at restaurants at irregular hours

medical_history.past_medical_conditions: Bronchopneumonia 7 years prior, influenza 10 months prior, possible earaches in childhood
medical_history.medications: Quinine, whiskey and hot lemonade for influenza symptoms

Doctor A.real_name: Richard C. Cabot, M.D. (Source: Edited By)

turn_1.speaker: Nurse A
turn_1.message: Good morning, sir. Welcome to Massachusetts General Hospital. I am Nurse A. What brought you in today?
turn_1.intention: Greeting and initial assessment of chief complaint.
turn_1.source_reference: Page 1: 'An American of fifty-five, formerly a dancing master, entered November 9 complaining of a feeling of general failure and weakness.'

turn_2.speaker: Patient
turn_2.timestamp: November 9, Upon Admission, immediately after Nurse A's greeting
turn_2.message: I've just been feeling generally weak and like a failure for a while now.
turn_2.context: Responding to nurse's question upon admission.
turn_2.source_reference: Page 1: 'complaining of a feeling of general failure and weakness.'

turn_3.speaker: Doctor A
turn_3.timestamp: November 9, Initial Examination, shortly after admission
turn_3.message: Hello, I'm Dr. Cabot.  Can you tell me more about this weakness you've been feeling? How long has it been going on?
turn_3.source_reference: Page 1: 'entered November 9 complaining of a feeling of general failure and weakness.'

turn_4.speaker: Patient
turn_4.timestamp: November 9, Initial Examination, immediately after Doctor A's question
turn_4.message: Well, it's been getting worse for about ten months, I'd say. Started with what I thought was the flu, then this cough just wouldn't go away. And then, about six months ago, this strange fluttering and awful pain started in my chest, near my... xiphoid thingy. It’s been on and off since then.
turn_4.intention: Describing symptom timeline and nature of chest pain and cough.
turn_4.context: Answering doctor's question about symptom duration.
turn_4.source_reference: Page 1: 'From this time he was symptom-free until ten months ago, when he had an attack of influenza...Six months ago he weighed 183 pounds, his usual weight. Then in less than a month a 'fluttering' sensation suddenly developed in the region of the xiphoid...'

turn_5.speaker: Doctor A
turn_5.timestamp: November 9, Initial Examination, after patient describes chest symptoms
turn_5.message: This chest pain, can you describe it more? What does it feel like?
turn_5.intention: Clarifying the nature of chest pain.
turn_5.source_reference: Page 1: 'sharply limited and associated with excruciating 'contracting, griping, tearing' pain.'

turn_6.speaker: Patient
turn_6.timestamp: November 9, Initial Examination, immediately after Doctor A's question about chest pain
turn_6.message: It's like... contracting, griping, tearing. Just awful.  And it comes and goes, but it's been pretty constant lately. Makes me cough more, and I’ve lost my appetite, and I’m constipated. Oh, and my spit is brownish sometimes.
turn_6.intention: Detailing chest pain characteristics and associated symptoms.
turn_6.context: Describing pain sensation and related symptoms.
turn_6.source_reference: Page 1: 'excruciating 'contracting, griping, tearing' pain. This remained more or less constant with remissions and relapses associated with increase of the cough, loss of appetite and constipation. At this time and later he noticed that the sputum was brownish...'

turn_7.speaker: Doctor A
turn_7.timestamp: November 9, Initial Examination, after patient describes sputum and appetite loss
turn_7.message: Brownish sputum... and you mentioned cough. How long have you had this cough?
turn_7.intention: Focusing on cough and sputum characteristics and duration.
turn_7.source_reference: Page 1: 'cough persisted with small amounts of sputum... he noticed that the sputum was brownish...'

turn_8.speaker: Patient
turn_8.timestamp: November 9, Initial Examination, responding to Doctor A's question about cough duration
turn_8.message: Well, the cough started after that flu ten months ago. It cleared up mostly, but a little cough stuck around, even when I felt better.  It's gotten worse again recently, though, with this chest stuff.
turn_8.intention: Explaining cough timeline in relation to influenza.
turn_8.source_reference: Page 1: 'Although the attack cleared up quickly and he felt perfectly well the cough persisted with small amounts of sputum...Six weeks ago he again began to lose weight, to feel weak, and to have increasing dyspnea and persistent slight cough.'

turn_9.speaker: Doctor A
turn_9.timestamp: November 9, Initial Examination, after patient mentions previous physician visit
turn_9.message: You mentioned seeing a doctor before? What did they say and do?
turn_9.intention: Gathering information about prior medical care.
turn_9.source_reference: Page 1: 'Five months ago he went to a physician, who made a diagnosis of pleurisy...'

turn_10.speaker: Patient
turn_10.timestamp: November 9, Initial Examination, responding to Doctor A's question about previous doctor's visit
turn_10.message: Yeah, about five months ago. He said it was pleurisy. He put me to bed and drained fluid from my chest twice. Three quarts the first time, then a quart a week later. It helped a lot at first, but then it came back.
turn_10.intention: Describing previous diagnosis and treatment for pleurisy.
turn_10.source_reference: Page 1: 'Five months ago he went to a physician, who made a diagnosis of pleurisy, put him to bed, and withdrew three quarts of clear yellowish fluid from his chest with great relief...At a second tap a quart of fluid similar to the first was withdrawn, with great relief.'

turn_11.speaker: Doctor A
turn_11.timestamp: November 9, Physical Examination, after history taking
turn_11.message: Alright, let's have a listen to your chest now. Just breathe normally.
turn_11.source_reference: Page 2: 'Lung signs as shown in the diagram.'

turn_12.speaker: Doctor A
turn_12.timestamp: November 9, Physical Examination, after lung auscultation
turn_12.message: (To Nurse A, whispering) Note the flattened right back of the chest and the lung signs as indicated here [referring to diagram]. Also, check for reflexes and Kernig's and Brudzinski's signs.
turn_12.intention: Directing nurse for specific examination findings.
turn_12.source_reference: Page 2: 'Chest flattened in the right back. Lung signs as shown in the diagram...Suggestion of Kernig and definite Brudzinsky.'

turn_13.speaker: Nurse A
turn_13.timestamp: November 9, Physical Examination, after performing reflex and meningeal sign checks.
turn_13.message: Doctor, reflexes are present, and there is a suggestion of Kernig and a definite Brudzinski sign.
turn_13.context: Communicating physical exam results to the doctor.
turn_13.source_reference: Page 2: 'Suggestion of Kernig and definite Brudzinsky.'

turn_14.speaker: Doctor A
turn_14.timestamp: November 9, Physical Examination, after neurological exam.
turn_14.message: We're going to do a few tests, including a chest X-ray and a spinal tap, to get a better idea of what's going on. We'll also get some blood and urine samples.

turn_15.speaker: Doctor A
turn_15.timestamp: November 9, after initial tests, reviewing lumbar puncture results
turn_15.message: Lumbar puncture fluid is clear, colorless, normal hydrodynamics, only 3 cells, protein 100, sugar 0.047, negative for alcohol, globulin, Wassermann and gold. Not much to see here initially.
turn_15.source_reference: Page 2: 'Lumbar punctures. November 9. 10 cc. of clear colorless fluid. No pellicle formed. Hydrodynamics normal. Rapid rise and fall...3 cells. Total protein 100. Sugar 0.047. November 9.'

turn_16.speaker: Doctor E
turn_16.timestamp: Around November 12-18, during X-ray review meeting
turn_16.message: Doctor Cabot, take a look at this chest X-ray. Notice the diaphragm is higher on the left.  There's extensive fine mottling throughout both lung fields, especially around the left hilus and mid-chest. It looks miliary.
turn_16.intention: Presenting and interpreting chest X-ray findings.
turn_16.context: Radiology consultation and review of imaging.
turn_16.source_reference: Page 3: 'Dr. Merrill: The first thing noticed is the inequality in the height of the diaphragm...The lungs show, as we see here, extensive fine mottling of both sides...'

turn_17.speaker: Doctor A
turn_17.timestamp: Around November 12-18, during X-ray review meeting, after Dr. Merrill's interpretation
turn_17.message: Miliary... tuberculosis or a septic process, then?  Interesting, this plate really changes things.
turn_17.intention: Considering differential diagnoses based on X-ray findings.
turn_17.context: Formulating differential diagnosis based on radiology.
turn_17.source_reference: Page 4: 'So I should think from the picture that the two most probable conditions which would give this appearance would be miliary tuberculosis or a septic process...It turns my ideas right around.'

turn_18.speaker: Doctor A
turn_18.timestamp: Around November 18, after second lumbar puncture
turn_18.message: The second lumbar puncture on the 18th shows 250 cells, mostly large mononuclears, high protein at 211, and positive for alcohol and ammonium sulphate.  This is more suggestive of meningitis now.
turn_18.source_reference: Page 2: 'Lumbar punctures. November 18. 25 cc of slightly opalescent colorless fluid...250 cells, large mononuclears (large cells with pseudopodic processes) 60%, lymphocytes 39%, polynuclears 1%...Total protein 211...Alcohol and ammonium sulphate strongly positive.'

turn_19.speaker: Doctor A
turn_19.timestamp: Around November 20-22, during discussion with colleagues
turn_19.message: So, putting it all together - miliary lung findings on X-ray, now meningeal irritation and changes in the spinal fluid...  It really points to miliary tuberculosis, doesn't it?
turn_19.intention: Synthesizing clinical and diagnostic findings to reach a diagnosis.
turn_19.source_reference: Page 4: 'Differential Diagnosis...We have evidence pointing to two groups of lesions, in the lungs and in the spinal cord...I know of but one type of meningitis that links itself up with pulmonary symptoms, and that is tuberculous...leaning very heavily, as I do, on this x-ray plate, I do not see how we can make any diagnosis save miliary tuberculosis.'

turn_20.speaker: Doctor D
turn_20.timestamp: Around November 20-22, during discussion with colleagues, responding to Dr. Cabot
turn_20.message: Yes, miliary tuberculosis seems most likely. The history of 'influenza' ten months ago could have been the start of it, even though the lung lesions don't look chronic.
turn_20.intention: Supporting miliary tuberculosis diagnosis and considering symptom timeline.
turn_20.source_reference: Page 4: 'Looking back I suppose we may say his 'influenza' attack of ten months ago was probably connected with his tuberculosis and that he has had it ever since...Yet if we say that, it is hard to say why there are not more chronic lesions in the lung.'

turn_21.speaker: Nurse A
turn_21.message: Doctor, the patient is much worse today. He seems irrational, isn't responding properly, and his breathing is very labored – Cheyne-Stokes respiration.
turn_21.source_reference: Page 2: 'November 22 he was much worse, with Cheyne-Stokes respiration.'

turn_22.speaker: Doctor A
turn_22.timestamp: November 22, after Nurse A reports worsening condition
turn_22.message: Pupils not reacting to light, bilateral Kernig, Oppenheim and Gordon signs... This is consistent with advancing meningitis and neurological decline. Continue comfort measures.
turn_22.intention: Assessing neurological status and confirming poor prognosis.
turn_22.source_reference: Page 2: 'The pupils did not react to light. There was definite bilateral Kernig, Oppenheim and Gordon...He became delirious.'

turn_23.speaker: Nurse A
turn_23.message: Doctor, the patient passed away this morning.

turn_24.speaker: Doctor F
turn_24.message: The autopsy confirms miliary tuberculosis, affecting the lungs, liver, spleen, and kidneys, and tuberculous meningitis. We also found a chronic TB focus at the apex of the right lung.
turn_24.source_reference: Page 5: 'Dr. Richardson : The tuberculosis in this case manifested itself as tuberculous meningitis and miliary tuberculosis of the lungs, liver, spleen, and rather well marked in the kidneys...There was a focus of tuberculosis in one of the bronchial glands and an area of chronic tuberculosis in the apical region of the right lung.'

turn_25.speaker: Doctor A
turn_25.timestamp: Post-mortem discussion, after Dr. Richardson's report
turn_25.message: So, our clinical diagnosis was correct. Miliary tuberculosis and tuberculous meningitis. The X-ray and spinal fluid findings were key in pointing us in the right direction, despite my initial cardiac misinterpretation.
turn_25.intention: Reflecting on the clinical diagnostic process and accuracy.
turn_25.source_reference: Page 4: 'CLINICAL DIAGNOSIS (FROM HOSPITAL RECORD) Miliary tuberculosis. Tuberculous meningitis...DR. RICHARD C. CABOT's DIAGNOSIS Miliary tuberculosis of the lungs, brain, spinal cord, liver, spleen, kidneys. Tuberculous meningitis...ANATOMICAL DIAGNOSIS 1. Primary fatal lesions Chronic tuberculosis of the apex of the right lung. Miliary tuberculosis of the lungs, liver, spleen and kidneys. Tuberculous meningitis.'

presentation.chief_complaint: Feeling of general failure and weakness
presentation.history_of_present_illness: 10 months of progressive symptoms starting with influenza-like illness, persistent cough, chest fluttering and pain, loss of appetite, constipation, dyspnea, weight loss, and neurological symptoms towards the end.
presentation.physical_exam: Emaciated elderly man, dyspneic, orthopneic, weak, cachectic, dull chest pain on sudden movement, stiff neck, bad teeth, pyorrhea, red throat, flattened right back chest, abnormal lung sounds, abdominal tenderness and spasm in right upper quadrant, enlarged liver, coarse tremor of hands and tongue, Kernig and Brudzinski signs, hemorrhoids.

laboratory_data.value: Sp. gr. 1.022-1.026, cloudy at times, occasional leucocytes, 5-10 RBCs/HPF
Clear, colorless, 3 cells, Total protein 100 mg/dL, Sugar 0.047 g/dL
laboratory_data.reference_range: Normal hydrodynamics, negative for Alcohol, globulin, Wassermann, gold solution

laboratory_data.value: Slightly opalescent, 250 cells (60% large mononuclears, 39% lymphocytes, 1% polynuclears), Total protein 211 mg/dL, Sugar 0.0295 g/dL
laboratory_data.reference_range: Normal hydrodynamics, positive for Alcohol and ammonium sulphate, negative Wassermann, gold solution, no TB found

imaging.description: Diaphragm high on both sides, higher on the left, irregular outline, fine mottled dullness throughout both lung fields, most marked around left hilus and midchest, no evidence of old TB at apex.

procedures.description: Attempted in eighth right interspace below scapula and midaxillary line, yielded bloody fluid (2cc, not from cavity) in first attempt, no fluid in second.

timeline_events.event: Fluttering sensation and chest pain, change in sputum color, dyspnea, constipation, loss of appetite, peculiar food cravings
Physician visit, diagnosis of pleurisy, two chest taps with fluid removal
Weight loss, weakness, increasing dyspnea, persistent cough
Bedridden, drowsiness, excessive sleep, feeling cold
Admission to hospital, initial examination, chest tap, lumbar puncture
Aspirin and Veronal orders, rectal glucose taps
Second lumbar puncture, patient much worse, irrational, pupils non-reactive, Kernig, Oppenheim, Gordon signs

final_diagnoses: Chronic tuberculosis of the apex of the right lung (Anatomical)
Miliary tuberculosis of the lungs, liver, spleen and kidneys (Anatomical)
